If you need a specific example for ServiceTier: ```tsp /** * Service tier for deployment. Possible values: * 1. Basic: Entry-level tier. * 2. Standard: Recommended tier. * 3. Premium: Advanced tier for large workloads. */ union ServiceTier { ... } ``` And for Response model, ensure any lists or references are in plain sentences and do not use block quotes or repeated links.\\n2. Or you can disable the sphinx environment within the pyproject.toml for the problematic package. By that way you won't hit these sphinx failures.\\n```\\n[tool.azure-sdk-build]\\nsphinx = false\\n```\"}"}]
groundedness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"To resolve the Python doc generation errors (unexpected indentation, block quote issues, duplicate explicit target names, and bullet list formatting) when emitting from TypeSpec to Python using tsp-client, you need to update your TypeSpec documentation comments and model definitions to be compatible with Sphinx and Python docstring formatting rules.\\n\\n**Key actions:**\\n\\n1. **Bulleted Lists and Block Quotes:**\\n   - In TypeSpec, documentation comments support CommonMark markdown, but Sphinx (used for Python docs) is sensitive to indentation and blank lines, especially for lists and block quotes.\\n   - Ensure that any bulleted lists in your `@doc` or block comments have a blank line before and after the list, and that list items are properly indented. For example:\\n     ```typespec\\n     /**\\n      * This is a summary.\\n      *\\n      * - Item one\\n      * - Item two\\n      *\\n      * More text after the list.\\n      */\\n     ```\\n   - Avoid mixing block quotes and lists without blank lines between them.\\n\\n2. **Duplicate Explicit Target Names:**\\n   - This error is usually caused by repeated markdown links with the same text (e.g., `[learn more](...)`) in the same docstring. Ensure that each link text is unique or only appears once per docstring.\\n   - If you need multiple links, use different link texts or combine them into a single sentence.\\n\\n3. **Unexpected Indentation and Unindent Errors:**\\n   - These are typically caused by inconsistent indentation in doc comments or by starting/ending lists or block quotes without blank lines.\\n   - Always start block comments and lists with a blank line, and end them with a blank line.\\n   - Avoid mixing markdown constructs (lists, quotes, code blocks) without clear separation.\\n\\n4. **ServiceTier Union Formatting:**\\n   - For unions like `ServiceTier`, if you have a doc comment with a bullet list, ensure it is formatted as described above. For example:\\n     ```typespec\\n     /**\\n      * Service tier options:\\n      *\\n      * - auto\\n      * - default\\n      * - flex\\n      * - scale\\n      * - priority\\n      */\\n     union ServiceTier {\\n       \\\"auto\\\",\\n       \\\"default\\\",\\n       \\\"flex\\\",\\n       \\\"scale\\\",\\n       \\\"priority\\\",\\n     }\\n     ```\\n\\n5. **Response Model Documentation:**\\n   - For the `Response` model, review all doc comments for properties and the model itself. Ensure that any lists, code blocks, or block quotes are separated by blank lines and properly indented.\\n   - If you have nested documentation, keep indentation consistent and avoid starting a new markdown construct immediately after another without a blank line.\\n\\n6. **General TypeSpec Docstring Best Practices:**\\n   - Use the TypeSpec formatter to ensure consistent indentation and layout ([see style guide](https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/style-guide)).\\n   - Use block comments (`/** ... */`) for multi-line documentation and ensure markdown constructs are separated by blank lines.\\n   - Avoid duplicate link texts and ensure all markdown is valid CommonMark.\\n\\n**Next steps:**\\n- Update your TypeSpec files to follow these documentation formatting rules.\\n- Re-run `tsp-client update` and rebuild your Python docs (`tox run -e sphinx ...`).\\n- If errors persist, check the generated Python docstrings for problematic markdown and adjust your TypeSpec comments accordingly.\\n\\nThis approach will resolve the Sphinx docstring errors and ensure your Python SDK documentation builds cleanly.\", \"context\": Main TypeSpec entry point for the service\\\\r\\\\n- `tspconfig.yaml` - TypeSpec compilation configuration with OpenAPI/SDK emitter options\\\\r\\\\n- Additional `*.tsp` files - Supporting TypeSpec files for the service\\\\r\\\\n- `examples/\\\\u003capiVersion\\\\u003e/` - name\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAzure services should not be using decorators from the OpenAPIs libraries(`@azure-tools/openapi`, `@azure-tools/typespec-autorest` or `@azure-tools/openapi3`) in their spec.\\\\r\\\\nUsing those decorators is usually a sign that the spec is either not following the correct Azure or trying to match exactly a particular OpenAPI spec which should be a non-goal.\\\\r\\\\nThose decorators are only meant to be read by the openapi emitters which means this might achieve the correct OpenAPI output but other emitters(client SDK, service, etc.) will not be able to understand them and will see a broken representation of the spec.\\\\n\\\\n## Decorators and their alternatives\\\\n\\\\n| OpenAPI Decorator                    | Alternative                                                                                                                                                     |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------------------------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `@example` `@extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-examples\\\\\\\", `       | [See examples doc](../../../migrate-swagger/faq/x-ms-examples.mdx)                                                                                              |\\\\r\\\\n| `@extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-client-flatten\\\\\\\", ` | Use [`@flattenProperty`](../../typespec-client-generator-core/reference/decorators.md#@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.flattenProperty)                       |\\\\r\\\\n| `@extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-mutability\\\\\\\", `     | Use [`@visibility` decorator](https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-decorators#@visibility)                                                        |\\\\r\\\\n| `@extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-enum\\\\\\\", `           | [Enum extensibility doc](../../../troubleshoot/enum-not-extensible.md)                                                                                          |\\\\r\\\\n| `@extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-identifiers\\\\\\\", `    | Use [`@identifiers`](../../azure-resource-manager/reference/decorators.md#@Azure.ResourceManager.identifiers)                                                   |\\\\r\\\\n| `@operationId`                       | Name your interface and operation accordingly                                                                                                                   |\\\\r\\\\n| `@useRef`                            | This should not be used, define the types correctly in TypeSpec. For ARM common types read the [Arm docs](../../..\\\\n\\\\n|\\\\r\\\\n| `@operationId`                       | Name your interface and operation accordingly                                                                                                                   |\\\\r\\\\n| `@useRef`                            | This should not be used, define the types correctly in TypeSpec. For ARM common types read the [Arm docs](../../../getstarted/azure-resource-manager/step00.md) |\\\\r\\\\n| `@info`                              | Use versioning library for `version` and `@service` Directory\\\\n\\\\nWhen migrating existing SDKs or working with brownfield services, you might need to place generated code in a specific subdirectory, like `_generated`. For these scenarios, you can use the [`namespace` configuration option](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/typespec-client-generator-core/reference/emitter/#namespace) in your `tspconfig.yaml` file.\\\\r\\\\nIf you want the published SDK to follow closely with the package structure and namespaces in your TypeSpec file, you should also pass in the `package-name` flag with the desired value.\\\\n\\\\n### Using the `namespace` Flag\\\\n\\\\nThe `namespace` option allows you to specify where the generated code should be placed within your package structure. This is particularly useful for cases where you want to:\\\\r\\\\n1. Keep generated code isolated in a dedicated subdirectory\\\\r\\\\n2. Maintain backward compatibility with existing SDK structures\\\\r\\\\n3. Separate generated code from hand-written code\\\\r\\\\n#### Example Configuration\\\\r\\\\nIn this example, we will take you through emitting generated code into a specific subdirectory (like `_generated`), with the idea that you will be fully-wrapping the generated code. Add the following to your `tspconfig.yaml`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cTabs\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cTabItem label=\\\\\\\"tspconfig.yaml\\\\\\\" default\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nemitters:\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"@typespec/http-client-python\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    namespace: \\\\\\\"azure.keyvault.certificates._generated\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    package-name: \\\\\\\"azure-keyvault-certificates\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/TabItem\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cTabItem label=\\\\\\\"TypeSpec File\\\\\\\"\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Azure.KeyVault.Certificates;\\\\r\\\\n@service({\\\\r\\\\n  title: \\\\\\\"Azure Key Vault Certificate It contains a clickable link to MS documentation (note the special format and double-underscore necessary to make this work). Following the general description of the method is a **required new line** and then documentation for each of the parameters, optional keyword arguments, returned objects, and potentially raised errors.\\\\r\\\\nPositional parameters can be documented in one-line or two-lines. Both options can be used in a single docstring for documenting different parameters without issue.\\\\r\\\\n1. This option works best for parameters that are one of the basic types (`str`, `int`, `bool`, `bytes`, `float`, etc.)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n:param \\\\u003ctype\\\\u003e \\\\u003cparam_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cDescription of the parameter\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n2. This option works best for parameters that use custom models or have many different options\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n:param \\\\u003cparam_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cDescription of the parameter\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n:type \\\\u003cparam_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cparam_type\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOptional keyword arguments can be documented in one-line or two-lines. The convention is a short line ending with a period, two new lines, followed by a longer description. Below is an example of a full docstring from `azure-ai-formrecognizer`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n    @distributed_trace\\\\r\\\\n    def begin_training(self, training_files_url, use_training_labels, **kwargs):\\\\r\\\\n        # type: (str, bool, Any) -\\\\u003e LROPoller[CustomFormModel]\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"Create and train a custom model.\\\\r\\\\n        The request must include a `training_files_url` parameter that is an\\\\r\\\\n        externally accessible Azure storage blob container URI (preferably a Shared Access Signature URI). Note that\\\\r\\\\n        a container URI (without SAS) is accepted only when the container is public. \\\\r\\\\n        See `SAS container details\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\u003chttps://docs.microsoft.com/azure/cognitive-services/form-recognizer/build-training-data-set\\\\u003e`__\\\\r\\\\n        for more details.\\\\r\\\\n        Models are trained using documents that are of the following content type - 'application/pdf',\\\\r\\\\n        'image/jpeg', 'image/png', 'image/tiff', or 'image/bmp'. Other types of content in the container is ignored.\\\\r\\\\n        :param str training_files_url: An Azure Storage blob container's SAS URI. A container URI (without SAS)\\\\r\\\\n            can be used if the container is public. For more information on setting up a training data set, see:\\\\r\\\\n            https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/cognitive-services/form-recognizer/build-training-data-set\\\\r\\\\n        :param bool use_training_labels: Whether to train with labels or not. Corresponding labeled files must\\\\r\\\\n            exist in the blob container if set to `True`.\\\\r\\\\n        :keyword str prefix: A case-sensitive prefix string to filter documents in the source path for\\\\r\\\\n            training. For example, when using a Azure storage blob URI, use the prefix to restrict sub\\\\r\\\\n            folders for training.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003cparam_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cparam_type\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOptional keyword arguments can be documented in one-line or two-lines. This option works best for keyword args that are one of the basic types (`str`, `int`, `bool`, `bytes`, `float`, etc.)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n:keyword \\\\u003ctype\\\\u003e \\\\u003ckeyword_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cDescription of the keyword\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n2. This option works best for keyword that use custom models or have many different options\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n:keyword \\\\u003ckeyword_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cDescription of the keyword\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n:paramtype \\\\u003ckeyword_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003ckeyword_type\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe returned object is documented on two lines, the first describing what the returned object is and the second describing what the returned type is.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n:return: \\\\u003cDescription of the returned object\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n:rtype: \\\\u003cType of the returned object\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nFinally, describe the possible errors raised by a method:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n:raises \\\\u003cerror1\\\\u003e, \\\\u003cerror2\\\\u003e, or \\\\u003cerror3\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cdescription\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAll of the above information needs to be added for each public method and there **needs to be a newline after the above docstrings**. There are additional options for including examples and version specific additions.\\\\r\\\\nFor adding a version specific change use the `versionadded` docstring:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n.. versionadded:: \\\\u003cversion_number\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAdditional sphinx directives are documented [here](https://review.learn.microsoft.com/help/onboard/admin/reference/python/documenting-api#supported-sphinx-directives)\\\\n\\\\n:param bool use_training_labels: Whether to train with labels or not. response_completeness_sample_input: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"To resolve the Python doc generation errors (unexpected indentation, block quote issues, duplicate explicit target names, and bullet list formatting) when emitting from TypeSpec to Python using tsp-client, you need to update your TypeSpec documentation comments and model definitions to be compatible with Sphinx and Python docstring formatting rules.\\n\\n**Key actions:**\\n\\n1. **Bulleted Lists and Block Quotes:**\\n   - In TypeSpec, documentation comments support CommonMark markdown, but Sphinx (used for Python docs) is sensitive to indentation and blank lines, especially for lists and block quotes.\\n   - Ensure that any bulleted lists in your `@doc` or block comments have a blank line before and after the list, and that list items are properly indented. For example:\\n     ```typespec\\n     /**\\n      * This is a summary.\\n      *\\n      * - Item one\\n      * - Item two\\n      *\\n      * More text after the list.\\n      */\\n     ```\\n   - Avoid mixing block quotes and lists without blank lines between them.\\n\\n2. **Duplicate Explicit Target Names:**\\n   - This error is usually caused by repeated markdown links with the same text (e.g., `[learn more](...)`) in the same docstring. Ensure that each link text is unique or only appears once per docstring.\\n   - If you need multiple links, use different link texts or combine them into a single sentence.\\n\\n3. **Unexpected Indentation and Unindent Errors:**\\n   - These are typically caused by inconsistent indentation in doc comments or by starting/ending lists or block quotes without blank lines.\\n   - Always start block comments and lists with a blank line, and end them with a blank line.\\n   - Avoid mixing markdown constructs (lists, quotes, code blocks) without clear separation.\\n\\n4. **ServiceTier Union Formatting:**\\n   - For unions like `ServiceTier`, if you have a doc comment with a bullet list, ensure it is formatted as described above. For example:\\n     ```typespec\\n     /**\\n      * Service tier options:\\n      *\\n      * - auto\\n      * - default\\n      * - flex\\n      * - scale\\n      * - priority\\n      */\\n     union ServiceTier {\\n       \\\"auto\\\",\\n       \\\"default\\\",\\n       \\\"flex\\\",\\n       \\\"scale\\\",\\n       \\\"priority\\\",\\n     }\\n     ```\\n\\n5. **Response Model Documentation:**\\n   - For the `Response` model, review all doc comments for properties and the model itself. Ensure that any lists, code blocks, or block quotes are separated by blank lines and properly indented.\\n   - If you have nested documentation, keep indentation consistent and avoid starting a new markdown construct immediately after another without a blank line.\\n\\n6. **General TypeSpec Docstring Best Practices:**\\n   - Use the TypeSpec formatter to ensure consistent indentation and layout ([see style guide](https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/style-guide)).\\n   - Use block comments (`/** ... */`) for multi-line documentation and ensure markdown constructs are separated by blank lines.\\n   - Avoid duplicate link texts and ensure all markdown is valid CommonMark.\\n\\n**Next steps:**\\n- Update your TypeSpec files to follow these documentation formatting rules.\\n- Re-run `tsp-client update` and rebuild your Python docs (`tox run -e sphinx ...`).\\n- If errors persist, check the generated Python docstrings for problematic markdown and adjust your TypeSpec comments accordingly.\\n\\nThis approach will resolve the Sphinx docstring errors and ensure your Python SDK documentation builds cleanly.\", \"ground_truth\": \"The Sphinx docstring errors you're seeing in the generated Python SDK (unexpected indentation, block quote ends without a blank line, duplicate explicit target names, bullet/definition list issues) are caused by how TypeSpec documentation comments are emitted into Python docstrings, especially when those comments use Markdown or formatting that doesn't map cleanly to reStructuredText (reST), which Sphinx expects.\\nTo resolve these errors, there are two possible solutions:\\n1. You need to ensure that the TypeSpec doc comments for the Response model and ServiceTier union are written in a way that avoids problematic Markdown constructs and closely follows what Sphinx/reST expects.\\nHere are practical steps:\\n- **Bullet/Definition List Formatting:** - Avoid using Markdown bullet lists (`*`, `-`, or `+`) or definition lists in your TypeSpec doc comments. Instead, use plain sentences, or, if you need a list, format it as numbered items with clear line breaks between each item. - If you must use a list, add a blank line before and after the list, and ensure each item starts on a new line. Do not nest lists or use complex indentation.\\n- **Inline Strong/Emphasis Markup:** - If you use `**bold**` or `*italic*` in TypeSpec comments, Sphinx may misinterpret these if not balanced. Prefer using plain text or ensure that every start marker has a matching end marker.\\n- **Explicit Targets (Links):** - If you use `[Learn more](url)` in doc comments, emitting these into Python docstrings can result in duplicate explicit target names. Use plain URLs or avoid repeating the same anchor text multiple times.\\n- **Block Quotes:** - Avoid using Markdown block quotes (`>`) in TypeSpec doc comments. If you need to highlight something, use plain sentences.\\n- **Unexpected Indentation:** - Ensure all TypeSpec doc comments are left-aligned, with no leading spaces or tabs before the text, unless you are deliberately creating a code block. For code blocks, use triple backticks and add blank lines before and after the block.\\n- **General Style:** - Write documentation in simple paragraphs. Do not mix Markdown with reST, and avoid complex formatting. - Example of a safe docstring for a model property: ```tsp /** * The list of available service tiers. Possible values include: * 1. Basic - Entry-level tier. * 2. Standard - Recommended for most workloads. * 3. Premium - Advanced tier for high throughput. */ ``` - Avoid: ```tsp /** * - Basic * - Standard * - Premium */ ``` **Actionable Steps:** - Go to your TypeSpec definitions for Response and ServiceTier, and revise any doc comments containing bullet lists, definition lists, block quotes, repeated anchor text, or excessive indentation. Replace with simple sentences or numbered lists as above. - After making these changes, regenerate the Python SDK and run the Sphinx build again. The warnings/errors should be resolved. - For reference on Python docstring formatting and Sphinx compatibility, see the Azure Python SDK [docstring guidelines](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/docstring.md). If you need a specific example for ServiceTier: ```tsp /** * Service tier for deployment. Possible values: * 1. Basic: Entry-level tier. * 2. Standard: Recommended tier. * 3. Premium: Advanced tier for large workloads. */ union ServiceTier { ... } ``` And for Response model, ensure any lists or references are in plain sentences and do not use block quotes or repeated links.\\n2. Or you can disable the sphinx environment within the pyproject.toml for the problematic package. By that way you won't hit these sphinx failures.\\n```\\n[tool.azure-sdk-build]\\nsphinx = false\\n```\"}"}]
